DE TOCQUEVILLE MEDAL
CONTEST TO BE HELD
APRIL 10th
Tryouts Will Be Held Before Dr.
French Within Next Week
Topic Announced

Announcement has been made
by Dr. French that the tryouts
for the De Tocqueville medal will
be held in about ten days. The
contest itself will take place on
April 10th at the assembly, and
the topic will be "Should the
French Government lease its
monopoly of matches and tobacco
to private enterprises?"
The contestants, who are not
limited 'to any class, will deliver
on this topic an original discussion of four minutes at the tryouts, and one of ten minutes at
the assembly.
The medal for the contest,
which has been received from
France, is given annually by the
Baron Pierre de Coubertin, a
French writer, in order to stimulate American students' interest
in French affairs. The topic of
the declamations must be upon
some subject closely connected
with France.

Jr., delivered an illustrated lecture on his experiences in South
America at a meeting of the Cosmopolitan Club, held last Saturday. night.

Singewald while on his trip across
Brazil were used to illustrate the
lecture. Dr. Singewald gave the
same lecture at an assembly during the early part of the scholastic
T
year.

the remainder of the year were
-discussed. A banquet of the foreign students at the end of the
year is anticipated.

The DeTocqueville Medal, which
was not offered last year, is one
of five given to American colleges
—Harvard and Princeton in the
East, Tulane of New Orleans in
the Sopth, receive one each, and
the fifth is contested for .between
California and Leland Stanford
on the west coast. Each of these
medals has a different name; the
one at Hopkins being named after
the distinguished French statesman.

A SIGN OF SPRING
A more sure sign of spring than the recent balmy weather
is the announcement that the Interfraternity Board has begun
its annual struggle to draw up a rushing agreement which will
be satsifactory to all parties concern6d.
Every year the board begins its work on or about the date
with, the pions hope that such an early start will give its
members time to carefully work out a system by unhurried
discussion and. adjustment of differences. And each year the
same bickerings and disputes have broken out, delay proceedings until about two weeks before the finals, when the fear of
having no agreement at. all has driven the delegates into a
hasty compromise.
For the sake of the peace of mind of the campus as a
whole, and of members of the Board in particular, we hope
that events proceed more smoothly than in the past, although,
we have no real reason to think that they will, for conditions
on the campus have changed very little, and human nature not
at all. However, we wish them success, and at the same time
take the liberty to offer a suggestion, which we think is advanced at a most opportune time, for, sinCe the agreement has
not been made, and therefore could not have possibly been
broken, this suggestion of ours will be based purely on principle.
The NEWS-LETTER would suggest, then, that, whatever type
of agreement is made, it contains provisions that will insure
speedy and severe punishment for all violations.
Our wish may be bloodthirsty, but it is sincere.

COMMON SENSE
The decision of the June Week Committee to dispense with

an out-of-town orchestra has shared the fate of most departures
from the old way of doing things in that it has evoked quite a
bit of adverse criticism, from both undergraduates and alumni.
There are perhaps some grounds for the opposition to the
Committee's policy. It has been argued that the name of a
nationally famous orchestra would go far toward popularizing
June Week, especially among the younger alumni. There is
also the consideration that the music furnished by one of the
"big" orchestras might be a trifle more pleasant to dance to,
but that seems to carry relatively little weight. The lure of
the name, the desire for Hopkins to do things in a "bigger and
better" way, are the main factors.
All of which is' true enough, if conditions were ideal. But
sordid and worldly motives have a way of affecting all our
decisions. And thus it is at Hopkins; the condition of the student pocket book has quite an influence on the June Week
policy.
June Week has always been a rather expensive affair, and
the largest item of expense has invariably been the out-of-town
''orchestras. The NEWS-LETTER heartily approves of a move that,
• detracting very slightly from the value of June Week, will
substantially lower the price.

DE TOCQUEVILLE MEDAL
CONTEST TO BE HELD
APRIL 10th
Tryouts Will Be Held Before Dr.
French Within Next Week
Topic Announced

Announcement has been made
by Dr. French that the tryouts
for the De Tocqueville medal will
be held in about ten days. The
contest itself will take place on
April 10th at the assembly, and
the topic will be "Should the
French Government lease its
monopoly of matches and tobacco
to private enterprises?"
The contestants, who are not
limited 'to any class, will deliver
on this topic an original discussion of four minutes at the tryouts, and one of ten minutes at
the assembly.
The medal for the contest,
which has been received from
France, is given annually by the
Baron Pierre de Coubertin, a
French writer, in order to stimulate American students' interest
in French affairs. The topic of
the declamations must be upon
some subject closely connected
with France.

Singewald while on his trip across
Brazil were used to illustrate the
lecture. Dr. Singewald gave the
same lecture at an assembly during the early part of the scholastic
T
year.

the remainder of the year were
-discussed. A banquet of the foreign students at the end of the
year is anticipated.

The DeTocqueville Medal, which
was not offered last year, is one
of five given to American colleges
—Harvard and Princeton in the
East, Tulane of New Orleans in
the Sopth, receive one each, and
the fifth is contested for .between
California and Leland Stanford
on the west coast. Each of these
medals has a different name; the
one at Hopkins being named after
the distinguished French statesman.

A SIGN OF SPRING
A more sure sign of spring than the recent balmy weather
is the announcement that the Interfraternity Board has begun
its annual struggle to draw up a rushing agreement which will
be satsifactory to all parties concern6d.
Every year the board begins its work on or about the date
with, the pions hope that such an early start will give its
members time to carefully work out a system by unhurried
discussion and. adjustment of differences. And each year the
same bickerings and disputes have broken out, delay proceedings until about two weeks before the finals, when the fear of
having no agreement at. all has driven the delegates into a
hasty compromise.
For the sake of the peace of mind of the campus as a
whole, and of members of the Board in particular, we hope
that events proceed more smoothly than in the past, although,
we have no real reason to think that they will, for conditions
on the campus have changed very little, and human nature not
at all. However, we wish them success, and at the same time
take the liberty to offer a suggestion, which we think is advanced at a most opportune time, for, sinCe the agreement has
not been made, and therefore could not have possibly been
broken, this suggestion of ours will be based purely on principle.
The NEWS-LETTER would suggest, then, that, whatever type
of agreement is made, it contains provisions that will insure
speedy and severe punishment for all violations.
Our wish may be bloodthirsty, but it is sincere.

COMMON SENSE
The decision of the June Week Committee to dispense with

an out-of-town orchestra has shared the fate of most departures
from the old way of doing things in that it has evoked quite a
bit of adverse criticism, from both undergraduates and alumni.
There are perhaps some grounds for the opposition to the
Committee's policy. It has been argued that the name of a
nationally famous orchestra would go far toward popularizing
June Week, especially among the younger alumni. There is
also the consideration that the music furnished by one of the
"big" orchestras might be a trifle more pleasant to dance to,
but that seems to carry relatively little weight. The lure of
the name, the desire for Hopkins to do things in a "bigger and
better" way, are the main factors.
All of which is' true enough, if conditions were ideal. But
sordid and worldly motives have a way of affecting all our
decisions. And thus it is at Hopkins; the condition of the student pocket book has quite an influence on the June Week
policy.
June Week has always been a rather expensive affair, and
the largest item of expense has invariably been the out-of-town
''orchestras. The NEWS-LETTER heartily approves of a move that,
• detracting very slightly from the value of June Week, will
substantially lower the price.
